page.title: 01LAUGHARNE, CARMARTHEN, DYFED
page.content: This section of West Wales covers the estuary of the River Taf on the west shore of Carmarthen Bay, and has dairy and stock farms on rolling hills, well wooded and watered with a considerable area of salt marshes. Laugharne Town, at the confluence of the Rivers Taf and Corran, developed on a Celtic settlement site and preserves its feudal system of local government (Charter 1307). It owns property and land which passes to 76 Burgesses who are Shareholders and farm their strips or let them, in the Open Field System. Two hamlets, each with an ancient Church, Llansadurnen 400' high west of Laugharne and Llandawke in a steep valley, contain a few farms and houses. The area is richly varied with many land and sea birds and profusions of wild flowers along banked lanes.
